headline.main: IMPORTANT FROM WASHINGTON.; Another Order from Secretary Stanton Regarding State Prisoners. A Commission to Decide upon the Cases of Those Remaining in Prison. General Dix and Edwards Pierrepoint Appointed Commissioners. Another Confiscation Bill Before Congress. Mr. Starke, of Oregon, Admitted to the Senate. A Rebel Conspiracy in Alexandria Broken Up.[OFFICIAL.]WAR BULLETIN.EXECUTIVE ORDER NO 2, IN RELATION TO THESTATE PRISONERS. OUR SPECIAL WASHINGTON DISPATCHES. CLEAR WEATHER. RUMORS ABOUT GEN. BANKS. THE TELEGRAPH CENSORSHIP. ENGLAND ON A PEACE FOOTING. GEN. SCOTT'S NOMINATION WITHDRAWN. THE NATIONAL FOUNDRY. DAVIS' CONFISCATION BILL. A CONSPIRACY IN ALEXANDRIA. MR. COCHRANE A BRIGADIER. MR. STARKE ADMITTED. MR. POWELL'S CASE. MR. BUCHANAN'S LIFE. PICKPOCKETS CAUGHT. AN OFFER FROM THE KING OF SIAM. THE NATIONAL FOUNDRY BILL. ON THE RETIRED LIST.

docs.abstract: Report on Congress proceedings; Stanton issues 2d order relative to prisoners of state; other news from Washington
docs.lead_paragraph: It is ordered, First That a special commission of two persons, one of military rank, and the other in civil life, be appointed to examine the cases of the State prisoners remaining in the military custody of the United States, and to determine whether in view of the public safety, and the existing rebellion, they should be discharged, or remain in military custody or be remitted to the civil tribunals for trial.

docs.snippet: At the meeting of the Board of Councilmen last evening, the Committee on National Affairs reported adversely to reimbursing the Third, Sixth and Twelfth Regiments for outlay in consequence of the war. The document was laid over.

headline.main: BOARD OF COUNCILMEN.; MAYOR OPDYKE'S FIRST VETO TROPHY FROM FORT DONELSON THE TAX LEVY.

docs.snippet: Cairo, to-day, is entangled in a complete web of mystery. A most important movement, both of land forces and gun and mortar boats, has been made, but its results have not yet come to the light. Its inception and surrounding circumstance I can give,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Cairo, to-day, is entangled in a complete web of mystery. A most important movement, both of land forces and gun and mortar boats, has been made, but its results have not yet come to the light. Its inception and surrounding circumstance I can give, and vaguely guess as to what has been accomplished.

headline.main: THE CAMPAIGN IN ARKANSAS.; THE PURSUIT OF PRICE, HIS EXPULSION FROM MISSOURI. THE ADVANCE INTO ARKANSAS.

docs.lead_paragraph: The approach of our army to Springfield was, it seems, entirely unexpected to PRICE and his army. Until the night before their entrance into the town, the rebels fell themselves entirely secure from molestation. The driving in of PRICE'S pickets on Wednesday night was the first intimation he had that our army was marching upon him.
